title: Do some cities in the United States have ugly laws to keep people with disabilities out of sight?
subtitle: Chicago, for example, one city enacted an "ugly law," did not repeal its decree prohibiting people who were "disfigured, maimed or otherwise maimed" from public places until 1974.
author: David Emery
vclaim: During the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, some American cities enacted so-called "ugly laws" prohibiting people who are considered to be "illicit, maimed, maimed or otherwise maimed to be an invisible, disgusting or inappropriate person" from public places.
